english_translation: Narrated by Ali: Hashim ibn al-Qasim told us, he said: Hizam narrated to us that he heard from his father, from Um Mu'abbad that she sent to the Prophet ﷺ a young she-camel (judha'ah) and he accepted it.

english_translation: Narrated by Said ibn Jumhan from Safina: The Prophet ﷺ said to Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman: 'These are the Caliphs after me.' However, this narration was not corroborated (mutataba'ah), because Umar ibn al-Khattab and Ali stated: 'The Prophet ﷺ did not appoint a caliph.' Hashim ibn al-Qasim said: He was al-Abbasi al-Kufi. The questioner said to Said: Did you meet Safina? He said: I met him in Makkah during the time of al-Hajjaj, and I stayed with him for several nights asking him about the hadith of the Prophet ﷺ.

narrators.name: Hayyan ibn Umayr
narrators.full_name: Hayyan ibn Umayr al-Jariri Abu al-Ala al-Basri

narrators.name: Safina
narrators.full_name: Safina ibn Asa'as ibn Azhar al-Awsi al-Madini

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Dhihak ibn Muzahim is Da'if (weak) - this is the first narrator, making the entire chain problematic
Hafs ibn Miysarah is also Da'if (weak)
Both weak narrators use transmission terms that could be indirect
Explicit contradiction noted in the source itself: Other companions (Umar and Ali) contradicted this hadith, stating the Prophet ﷺ did not appoint a caliph

potential_issues.issue: Two weak narrators (Da'if) at the beginning of the chain: Dhihak ibn Muzahim and Hafs ibn Miysarah
potential_issues.impact: Critical weakness making the entire chain unreliable for establishing authentic traditions

potential_issues.issue: Explicit contradiction documented in the source text
potential_issues.impact: The narration explicitly states it was 'not supported' (لَمْ يُتَابَعْ عَلَيْهِ) and contradicted by Umar ibn al-Khattab and Ali who said the Prophet ﷺ did not appoint a caliph

potential_issues.issue: Content contradicts well-established historical and hadith consensus
potential_issues.impact: The Prophet ﷺ is well-documented by authentic sources as not appointing a specific caliph, with the succession determined by consultation (Shura)

potential_issues.issue: Hafs ibn Miysarah uses indirect transmission (عَنْ) from a weak narrator
potential_issues.impact: Reduces reliability further as the connection is ambiguous

Topics: Succession of the Caliphate after the Prophet ﷺ
Question regarding appointment of specific caliphs
Dialogue about Prophet's ﷺ specification of successors

english_translation: Narrated from Abu Salamah Abd al-Rahman from Aisha from the Prophet ﷺ: 'Whoever lies about me intentionally.' Regarding the fighters, if they abstain from the first diya then the first; and if it was a woman. Ali narrated from al-Walid from al-Awza'i. Yahya ibn Abi Kathir said: From Abu Hurairah from the Prophet ﷺ regarding the diya. Muhammad ibn Amr said: From Abu Salamah from Abu Hurairah, the Prophet ﷺ said: 'Whoever lies about me.'

english_translation: From Abdullah ibn Amr: Umar asked the Companions of the Prophet ﷺ about the Night of Power (Laylat al-Qadr), so Ibn Abbas said: 'My Lord loves the number seven,' and mentioned the Quranic verse: 'And We have given you the seven oft-repeated (verses)' [Quran 15:87]. Abu Sa'id al-Ju'fi mentioned this, from Ibn Wahb, from Hayy ibn Abdullah, from Hayy. There is something questionable in its chain.

english_translation: Al-Ju'fi said: Ubaydullah ibn Thur told us, he heard his brother al-Hallal from Abd al-Majid ibn Wahb from Abi al-Hallal who asked Uthman about the gift of the Sultan. He said: It is the meat of a gazelle that was properly slaughtered. Musa also said: Harun ibn Musa told us, he heard Abd al-Hamid from Abi al-Hallal his statement.

english_translation: Al-Hasan ibn Bishr said: Al-Hakam ibn Abd al-Malik told us from Qatadah from Humayri ibn Bashir from Muqil ibn Yasar from the Prophet ﷺ something similar. It is also said: He is the one from whom al-Muthanna ibn Auf narrated, and he heard from Muqil.

narrators.name: Qatadah
narrators.full_name: Qatadah ibn Di'amah ibn Qatadah al-Sadusi

narrators.name: Humayri ibn Bashir

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Al-Hasan ibn Bishr is majhul (not well documented)

Secondary transmission information mentions al-Muthanna ibn Auf, complicating the chain further

english_translation: David ibn al-Mufaddal said: Hammad ibn Salamah told us from his father from Humayri ibn Karaathah who said: When al-Ablah (a region in Iraq) was conquered, they found a green shirt with slits at the chest, and their commander used to wear it on Friday.

chainIssues: Humayri ibn Karaathah is majhul (unknown/not well documented)
This is a maqtu' (cut) hadith - stops at narrator level without reaching Companions or Prophet ﷺ
The content is historical narrative about the conquest of al-Ablah, not a hadith from the Prophet ﷺ or Companions
Hammad ibn Salamah is noted to have experienced ikhtilat (confusion) in his later years

potential_issues.issue: Humayri ibn Karaathah is majhul (unknown/not well documented)
potential_issues.impact: Cannot verify reliability of the primary narrator for this account

potential_issues.issue: This is a maqtu' (cut) historical narrative, not a hadith
potential_issues.impact: Does not reach back to Companions or Prophet ﷺ; is only a historical account of events

potential_issues.issue: Hammad ibn Salamah experienced ikhtilat (confusion) in his later years
potential_issues.impact: Some narrations via Hammad from his later life may be affected, though this narration is described as coming from his father

potential_issues.issue: Content is historical description of clothing/events during conquests
potential_issues.impact: This is a historical narrative about an army commander's clothing, not a religious hadith
